texts.definition: Game elements used to distribute resources, often with different characteristics, without necessarily revealing the distribution.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements used to distribute resources, often with different characteristics, without necessarily revealing the distribution.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are common game elements in traditional games, most often rectangular with information only on one side and thin enough to easily stack and shuffle. They provide an easy way to randomize distribution and keep that distribution secret from players. The information can either be secret to all players, as for example when the game uses a stack from which cards are drawn, or known only to one player, as is the case in card games where each player has a card hand. The use of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> also allow game designers to choose the exact distribution, not only guaranteeing the overall chance for a value specified by a card to be drawn but also guaranteeing that certain values will appear during gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> do not need to be physical game elements; they can also be simulated in computer games.

While some purchased games come with all <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> in a game design, others require players to combine their <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> to be able and play. Other games expand the gameplay by adding expansions with <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>.
''Note:'' this pattern shared the same definition as <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> since the difference primarily concern material and ergonomics.
''Note:'' this pattern currents includes the pattern <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chips">Chips</link></style>.

The common deck of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>, used for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stress">Stress</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Whist">Whist</link></style>, consists of 52 cards split between four suits of 13 cards each, where the 13 cards are numbered from 2 to 10 and include a knight, queen, king and ace. Examples of games that use specialized decks include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bang!">Bang!</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fluxx">Fluxx</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Frank's%20Zoo">Frank's Zoo</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Munchkin">Munchkin</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Great%20Dalmuti">The Great Dalmuti</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thunderstone">Thunderstone</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Uno">Uno</link></style>.

Alternative card designs include the "card sets" of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Collectible%20Card%20Games">Collectible Card Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati:%20New%20World%20Order">Illuminati: New World Order</link></style>. In both of these several different categories of cards are mixed and are required to be used in order to win, some enabling actions, some acting as resources generators. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati:%20New%20World%20Order">Illuminati: New World Order</link></style> also uses spatial relationships of the <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> as a meaningful element of the gameplay.

<style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are not only used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style> but also in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> and sometimes in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>. For example, the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Talisman">Talisman</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> to randomize the contents of areas on the game board - and the card hands players possess are public inventories of items found - while in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style> they represent possible actions for players. The latest edition of the roleplaying game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> to depict the skills, talents, and reputations of players' characters. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/San%20Juan">San Juan</link></style> shows how a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>) can be converting into a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style>.
See The Penguin Encyclopedia of Card Games for numerous examples of other Card Games.

<style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can either function as support to a game or be the main game element. Regardless of which use is chosen, designing <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> consist of selecting what information should be on the <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>, what different types of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> should exist, and how many of each type should exist. They are very often used to create <style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style>. Many well-known card games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hearts">Hearts</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>, use the common card pack with 52 cards in four suits. Others, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Blackjack">Blackjack</link></style>, use several decks to increase the unpredictability of the gameplay. Some games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illuminati:%20New%20World%20Order">Illuminati: New World Order</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pandemic">Pandemic</link></style>, have cards with specific rules on them; this lets <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> provide local-available actions, and <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> between <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> quite often emerge in such games. A major design decision regarding the use of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> in games is whether they should make use of <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, the use of this makes card-based games into <style="Link"><link="collectible-card-games">Collectible Card Games</link></style> and is often combined with the pattern of <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Expansions">Expansions</link></style> with new <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>.

The difference between <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> and <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> is rather small; <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are easier to shuffle, typically contain more information while <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> make sturdier <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, can have more different forms including being much smaller, and can be fixed in place in relation to other <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>. For this reason, game designers considering using <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can also consider using <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are commonly used as <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>, potentially also with <style="Link"><link="stack-seeding">Stack Seeding</link></style> to guarantee certain distributions of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>, but even more commonly with <style="Link"><link="hands">Hands</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can be used to make actions possible directly or through <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, represent <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> or parts of <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>. A type of action only found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style> is <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>. Although not are common as for <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can be combined with <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> to create "<style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style>". As <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can represent <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> is often but not always used for regulating how <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are drawn or played; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Nertz">Nertz</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Speed">Speed</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stress">Stress</link></style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style> without <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can either be taken out of play after being used, making them <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> for the actions they represent, or be re-used through the use of <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style>. Another option is that <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are played to be put into play but activating them is limited through <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style> periods (typically by turning used cards sidewise, ''tapping'' them). Even games that do not re-use <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> often use <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style> to separate the cards that have been used from others, except for card games which use <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> are physical game elements, they make feasible candidates for support <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style> in a game.

Sets of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> allow game designers to determine exactly the distribution between different <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, events, or outcomes in a game while still providing <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>; the <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is very often achieved through making <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> of the <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>. Games with <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can quite easily be given <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Expansions">Expansions</link></style> through simply providing new <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>; this is a way to provide <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, and examples of games that have done this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pok%C3%A9mon%20Trading%20Card%20Game">Pok√©mon Trading Card Game</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thunderstone">Thunderstone</link></style>.

Since cards are two-sided, the information contained on the card can be distributed in various ways between the two-sides: having no information on one side (except that it is a card in the set) as is the case for traditional cards; marking functionally different cards on both sides but not the specific characteristics or placing one of several categories of information on both sides. This allows fine-tuning of the use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> in the game design, including using them as pure <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style> (<style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> cannot in themselves instantiate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> in games unless the types of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> and distributions are unknown to players). The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> possible by <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> allows <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> using them to be <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style> - <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> uses this to let traitors sabotage challenges with some risk of not being detected. Whenever players can keep count of which <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can remain to be played, this makes <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> played <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> advantageous.

When <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> provide <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> to players, they are a form of <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> and can represent <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>. This quite naturally opens up for <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> through acquiring new <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style>. The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> in any type of game opens up the possibility of <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style> as a way to distribute <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> to players. In games  with <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Cards</style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="cycle-deck-engines">Cycle Deck Engines</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bookkeeping-tokens">Bookkeeping Tokens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>
